data.vignette: In the pediatric ICU, a 6-year-old with severe viral myocarditis is on maximal ventilator and inotropes. The regional network has one ECMO circuit available, and the hospital’s policy is to offer ECMO to the next eligible child to avoid bedside rationing. This child technically meets criteria, but the team worries ECMO will likely mean prolonged sedation, bleeding, and neurologic injury with little chance of leaving the ICU. The ICU attending must decide whether to follow the allocation policy.
data.choice_1: Do not start ECMO and focus on comfort-directed care to avoid exposing the child to burdensome invasive treatment.
data.choice_2: Start ECMO per the network’s eligibility and queue policy, despite concern it may prolong suffering and complications.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Replace vague prognostic language (“will likely…with little chance”) with fixed qualitative statements that remove clinical ambiguity and keep the tension ethical. For example: “Without ECMO, death is expected within hours. With ECMO, the chance of survival to discharge is low, and the risk of major bleeding or neurologic injury is high.” Avoid implying ECMO is clearly futile.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: State the decision timeframe explicitly (e.g., “The decision must be made in the next 30 minutes as shock is worsening” or “before cannulation team arrives”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum missing decision-shaping facts and remove soft/interpretive phrasing. Specify whether the child has a surrogate/parents available and what they want (or that they are unreachable), and whether the policy is mandatory vs discretionary (“must” vs “may deviate with justification”). Keep only essential clinical context (current instability, expected trajectory without ECMO, qualitative benefit/harms with ECMO, the existence of the allocation rule).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Revise so neither option is obviously better. Avoid “little chance of leaving the ICU,” which makes ECMO seem near-futile. Instead, make ECMO offer a meaningful but limited possibility of recovery (low-to-moderate chance) with high burdens/complications, and clarify that foregoing ECMO likely leads to death soon. This preserves a genuine conflict between following a fairness policy vs individualized best-interest concerns.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic loading that makes one option dominate. Replace 'with little chance of leaving the ICU' with a qualitatively uncertain prognosis (e.g., 'outcome is uncertain and may include either recovery or prolonged dependence with complications'). Make both choices hinge on the same stable tension (duty to follow a fair allocation rule vs avoiding potentially burdensome, low-benefit treatment) rather than on a single pessimistic phrase.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the exact competing commitments so graders converge. Specify whether any other eligible children are expected/queued soon (e.g., 'another eligible child is expected to arrive within hours' or 'no other eligible child is currently waiting'). This makes the fairness/consistency stakes concrete and prevents the case from being read as mere futility vs treatment.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option is effectively dictated by futility norms or by policy obedience. (1) Remove or soften language implying ECMO is near-certainly nonbeneficial ('little chance'). (2) Add a reason ECMO could still be reasonable (e.g., 'some children recover cardiac function after several days on ECMO'). (3) Add a reason deviating from policy could be reasonable without being arbitrary (e.g., 'policy allows clinician override when expected benefit is very low' OR 'policy is strict, but bedside clinicians worry it forces harmful care'). Keep wording neutral and keep the vignette <=100 words.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden phrasing that steers away from ECMO. Suggested edits: change “burdensome invasive treatment” to “additional invasive life-support”; change “prolong suffering and complications” to “prolong intensive care with risk of complications”; change “little chance of leaving the ICU” to “uncertain likelihood of meaningful recovery/ICU discharge.” Also replace “technically meets criteria” with neutral “meets eligibility criteria.”

data.vignette: In a pediatric ICU, an 8-year-old with myocarditis is in worsening cardiogenic shock despite maximal medications. Without ECMO, death is expected within hours. With ECMO, some children recover heart function after several days, but major bleeding or neurologic injury can occur and meaningful recovery is uncertain. Hospital policy says any child meeting criteria should be offered ECMO, with bedside discretion to decline only if expected benefit is very low. The parents are present and insist on “everything.” Another ECMO-eligible child is expected to arrive later today. You are the attending; the cannulation team arrives in 30 minutes.
data.choice_1: Proceed with ECMO per eligibility policy and parental request.
data.choice_2: Decline ECMO now, documenting low expected benefit and reserving ECMO capacity for later arrivals.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove prognostic ambiguity and comparative framing. Replace “some children recover… meaningful recovery is uncertain” with fixed qualitative estimates (e.g., “ECMO offers a moderate chance of survival with meaningful recovery, but carries a high risk of devastating stroke/bleeding”). Avoid implying ECMO is clearly indicated by making benefit/risk qualitatively explicit and stable rather than vague.

key_information.suggested_changes: Cut non-essential detail and keep only decision-relevant facts; the narrative is far over 100 words and includes extraneous policy wording. Streamline to: setting (PICU), diagnosis (myocarditis), refractory cardiogenic shock, imminent death without ECMO, qualitative benefit/risk of ECMO, policy constraint (must offer unless benefit very low), competing anticipated ECMO need later today, parents request full treatment, decision needed in 30 minutes.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Reduce reliance on local policy language and clarify the ethically salient facts so the dilemma survives wording tweaks. Remove or shorten “Hospital policy says…” and instead state the clinical uncertainty about benefit and the immediate scarcity risk (e.g., “Only one ECMO circuit/team is available for the next 12 hours; another critically ill child may need it later today”). Keep choices framed as initiating ECMO vs not initiating due to uncertain benefit and scarcity.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the competing values less confounded by policy compliance and more by patient-centered benefit vs fair allocation. Add a brief line that the current child is eligible but prognosis is poor/uncertain, and that the later arrival is unknown severity (or similarly high likelihood of benefit) so graders don’t interpret this as simple triage. Avoid implying a rule-based answer by deleting “meeting criteria should be offered” and instead describe it as ‘usual practice’ with room for discretion.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is obviously mandated. Currently, imminent death + parental request + ‘policy says offer’ makes ECMO feel favored. Either (a) increase the burdens/low-likelihood-of-meaningful-recovery for this child in qualitative terms (e.g., severe neurologic injury already suspected, multi-organ failure), or (b) reduce the pull of policy/parents by noting parents understand risks but are divided/uncertain, and policy allows bedside refusal for marginal cases. Also avoid ‘reserve for later arrivals’ unless you specify credible, time-limited scarcity (single circuit/team) and uncertainty about who will need it.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Rephrase potentially value-laden or leading wording. Change “Without ECMO, death is expected within hours” to a less deterministic, clinically neutral phrasing such as “Without ECMO, prognosis is poor and may be rapidly fatal.” Change “parents … insist on ‘everything’” to “parents request full escalation, including ECMO.” Avoid wording that implies either futility or entitlement; keep prognosis language parallel for both options (e.g., pair potential for recovery with potential for serious complications without emphasizing one side).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential facts and remove policy/operational detail that doesn’t change the ethical frame. Suggested cuts: drop “after several days,” “meaningful,” and the full policy clause; replace with one sentence: “Hospital policy recommends offering ECMO when criteria are met, but allows attending discretion when benefit is very unlikely.” Consider removing “cannulation team arrives in 30 minutes” unless time pressure is central. Aim for ≤100 words by collapsing sentences and removing redundancies (e.g., ‘worsening… despite maximal medications’ → ‘refractory cardiogenic shock despite maximal support’).

data.vignette: You are the PICU attending. A 7-year-old with fulminant myocarditis has refractory cardiogenic shock despite maximal support. ECMO could offer a moderate chance of survival, but there is a high risk of devastating stroke or major bleeding, and worsening kidney and liver injury suggests a poor overall prognosis. Your hospital has only one ECMO circuit and team available for the next several hours; another critically ill child may arrive later today who could also require ECMO. The parents request full escalation, including ECMO. A decision is needed soon.
data.choice_1: Initiate ECMO for the child now, accepting the risks and that the circuit may not be available later.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate ECMO and continue non-ECMO intensive care, keeping the circuit available for a possible later child.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Specify which value is being benchmarked (e.g., Justice/resource allocation vs Beneficence to current patient) and add explicit details that make the tradeoff unambiguous: clarify ECMO survival probability and morbidity risk, describe expected benefit of ECMO for this child vs likely benefit for a potential arriving patient, and note the institutional triage policy (or absence of one) plus parents’ informed request and understanding of risks.

Make the tradeoff between individual beneficence/nonmaleficence and justice (single ECMO circuit for a possible incoming patient) more concrete by specifying the expected arrival time and likely benefit for the second child, and by clarifying that initiating ECMO now would occupy the circuit/team for days and preclude offering it to the later child. Include that parents request ECMO to highlight autonomy/surrogate preference but that institutional triage may override.

data.vignette:
You are the pediatric intensivist in a small regional children’s hospital during a severe RSV surge. The unit has one ECMO circuit and one on-call ECMO team. Both are currently idle, but if activated they will be committed to a patient for several days and cannot be used for another child.

A 3-year-old (16 kg) with RSV bronchiolitis has been intubated for 24 hours and is now in refractory hypoxemic respiratory failure despite maximal conventional ventilation, inhaled nitric oxide, paralysis, and prone positioning. The child has no major comorbidities and was previously healthy. The ECMO consultant estimates that veno-venous ECMO would offer a 55–65% chance of survival to discharge, but with significant risks: ~15% risk of major intracranial hemorrhage, ~10% risk of serious neurologic injury, and likely weeks of rehabilitation if the child survives.

While you are evaluating the child, your transfer center calls: a 7-year-old at a neighboring hospital with fulminant viral myocarditis is deteriorating on maximal inotropes and mechanical ventilation. The referring team requests urgent veno-arterial ECMO. They are 90 minutes away by ground, and their child’s predicted survival with VA-ECMO is 75–85% with lower expected long-term morbidity than the current patient. Without ECMO, the myocarditis patient is likely to die within hours.

Your hospital has no written ECMO triage policy for simultaneous or near-simultaneous candidates; decisions are made case-by-case by the attending intensivist with input from cardiology and the ECMO director. The 3-year-old’s parents, after a detailed discussion of benefits, risks (including stroke/bleeding), and uncertainty, explicitly request ECMO because they believe “we have to try everything,” and they demonstrate understanding that ECMO may prolong suffering without guaranteeing survival.

You must decide whether to initiate ECMO now for the 3-year-old, knowing it would consume the only circuit and team for days and almost certainly prevent offering ECMO to the incoming myocarditis patient, or to defer/decline ECMO for the current child to preserve the resource for the anticipated transfer.

choice_1.choice: Initiate VV-ECMO now for the 3-year-old with RSV after obtaining informed parental consent, accepting that the circuit/team will likely be unavailable to the incoming myocarditis patient.

choice_2.choice: Do not initiate ECMO for the 3-year-old at this time; continue maximal conventional care and reserve the ECMO circuit/team for the anticipated 7-year-old with myocarditis arriving in ~90 minutes.
